May it please yo
r
good L. Upon certaine intellig
e
ce
of
e Enemies continuance in
e places whiche I
signified about three daies agoe, it is generally
thought, that his intention is still to stay in those
quarters: partly to assure his levie out of
Ger-
many
, and partly to attend o
r
comming to
Nieu-
meghen
. For considering howe his nombers are
increased every day, it is feared very muche,
at
if o
r
army were past
e Wael, he might force us
to retire w
t
dommage and dishono
r
. Wherupon,
so smalle apparance being offered of
e Enemies re-
movall, and o
r
forces leesing time for all other ex-
ploites, it is resolved heere to day in a generall
meeting aswell of
e
Councel,
as of
e martial com-
maunders, that for
e better commoditie of refreshing
e army, and for attending w
at
e Enemie will en-
terprise upon it, all
e souldiers for a time shall
be placed in garrison. but so conveniently distri-
buted, as they may come against together in two or
three daies, to be soddainly imploied, before
e Enemie
can have knowledge of any enterprise towardes.
Moreover it hath bin earnestly requested by
e
states
of Zeland
, that some attempt should be given for
surprising of
Hulst
in
e land of Waes: w
ch
is a
place of good importance to those of
at Province, and
may force a great contrey to come in contribution.
The motion hath bin made, and is very well liked,
but no resoluti on is taken upon it. Nevertheles
it hath bin some occasion of this present repartition
of
e troupes into garrison: for that they thinke it
will availe for
e better execution of their pur-
pose on
e soddaine. I have by a
former acquainted yo
r
L. w
t
e offer of
e states
to
Mons
r
de Reibous
, in case
e army of Germany
could be drawen to come this way, to witte, of
1000
li
sterling in present pay, and of bridges and
boates, w
t
other like necessaries, to passe their army
fol.274v
over rivers. There is nowe an answear sent unto
them from
e
vicount of Turenne
and from Mons
r
de Reibous, w
ch
they addresse unto
us
Count Maurice.
That yo
r
L. might be informed, w
at
cause is preten-
ded,
at they have not accepted
at offer of
e states, I
have sent yo
w
e transcript of their letters to
e Count.
Mons
r
de Turenne will not seeme in his answear to
speake so plainely as
e other, who reporteth to Count
Maurice
e vicounts opinion of his inclination to the
having of those forces, w
ch
he thought was over faint
and cold, for a mater of that weight. And so it
was undoubtedly, when he writte his letter to
e vicount.
For
e offer from
e states was made at suche time,
as
e Enemies army was lodged in
e Betuwe,
and all
e contrey in suche perplexitie, as they dou-
bted very muche, unles they could procure to be
presently relieved w
t
some forraine assistance, a
great part of these quarters might be easely spoiled,
and the general state in daunger. But three
daies after
at
[writing]
offer, they obtened a victorie
upon
e Enemies horse, w
ch
caused them soddainly,
to forsake
e Betuwe, and quenched
at desire w
ch
e states had before, to calle in
e Germaines.
Then it was that Count Maurice writte his letter
to
e Vicount, not refusing to accomplishe what-
soever had bin offered, but somw
at
quailing in his
earnestnes in respect of intreaty, and leaving it
wholy to
e choise of
e vicount himself. For al-
aies before both
e Count and
e states had this
persuasion, that unles they should be driven to
some extremitie by the Enemie, a short aboade of
that army, could bring but litle benefit, and that
it could not be so short, but
at
e contrey thereby
would be dammified greatly. Of this conceat of
e Count I certified
S
r
Horace Pallavicine
at his
being w
t
e vicount, and as farre
[.]
as I remember
fol.275r
I writte
e same unto yo
r
L. Because it
may appeere by
e letter of Mons
r
de Reibous,
at
he reporteth so plainely what
e vicount had con-
ceaved, upon speciall affection that he beareth
to
e Count, it might peradventure be offensively
taken, if it should be understoode
at
e letter is
imparted, whiche I leave unto yo
r
L. to consider
as yo
w
please,
and so I take my humble leave.
From Arnham. Au
g
10 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
